title: 108_hr4090
content: The Act may be cited as the "Trade Adjustment Assistance Equity for Service Workers Act of 2004" and extends trade adjustment assistance to the services sector. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Equity for Service Workers Act of 2004 expands eligibility criteria for workers in service sector firms or public agencies under the Trade Act of 1974. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Equity for Service Workers Act of 2004 broadens eligibility criteria for workers in service sector firms or public agencies under the Trade Act of 1974 by including provisions for services directly competitive with those provided by the firm, subdivision, or public agency shifting to a foreign country. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Equity for Service Workers Act of 2004 expands eligibility for workers in service sector firms or public agencies under the Trade Act of 1974 by including services directly competitive with those moving to a foreign country. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Equity for Service Workers Act of 2004 broadens eligibility for workers in service sector firms or public agencies under the Trade Act of 1974 by including services directly competitive with those relocating abroad. The act also amends production processes, finishing, testing, and services for articles or services. The Secretary may determine increased imports of services from foreign countries if firms or customers accounting for at least 20% of sales certify to obtaining services abroad. The Secretary has the authority to make these determinations based on certifications from firms, subdivisions, or public agencies. The Secretary has the authority to obtain certifications through questionnaires or other means. Additionally, the Trade Act of 1974 is amended to increase training funds to $440,000,000. Definitions in the Act are also amended to include public agencies. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to define 'public agency' and 'service sector firm'. Section 245(a) is amended to remove a specific reference. SEC. 3. TRADE ADJUSTMENT ASSISTANCE FOR FIRMS AND INDUSTRIES. Trade Adjustment Assistance for firms under the Trade Act of 1974 is amended to include service sector firms in addition to agricultural firms. The amendments also cover assistance for firms producing articles or services directly competitive with others. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to include service sector firms and firms producing competitive articles or services. The Secretary may determine increased imports if customers of a firm accounting for at least 20% of sales certify they are obtaining such items from a foreign country. The Secretary has the authority to obtain certifications through questionnaires or other appropriate means. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to include service sector firms and firms producing competitive articles or services. The Secretary of Commerce is granted subpoena power for enforcement. Authorization of appropriations is increased to $32,000,000. The definition of a service sector firm is clarified. Industries now include services in addition to products. Section 2355(a) is amended to include "service" after "new product". Section 249 of the Trade Act of 1974 is amended to include service sector firms and firms producing competitive articles or services. Section 249 of the Trade Act of 1974 is amended to include subpoena authority. Section 282 of the Trade Act of 1974 is amended to include monitoring programs for imports of articles and services, domestic production of services, and changes in production or provision of services. Additionally, data collection and reporting on the services sector are required. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Equity for Service Workers Act of 2004 mandates data collection on adversely affected service workers by State, industry, and cause of dislocation. The Secretary of Commerce is required to conduct a study on improving data timeliness and coverage on trade in services, including identifying increased imports due to the relocation of US firms to foreign countries.
